mesh4d.analyse.visual.show_mesh_value_mask#

mesh4d.analyse.visual.show_mesh_value_mask(mesh: PolyData, points: Iterable, values: Iterable, k_nbr: int = 10, distance_upper_bound: float = 50, max_threshold: float | None = None, min_threshold: float | None = None, cmap: str = 'cool', is_save: bool = False, export_folder: str = '', export_name: str = 'screeenshot', **kwargs)[source]#

Show the 3D mesh with a value mask.

Parameters:

  • mesh (pyvista.core.pointset.PolyData) – The mesh to be shown with value mask.

  • points (Iterable) – An iterable containing the points to use for assigning values to the mesh vertices.

  • values (Iterable) – An iterable containing the values to assign to the mesh vertices based on their nearest point in points.

  • k_nbr (int, optional) – The number of nearest neighbors to consider when assigning values to the mesh vertices. Default is 10.

  • distance_upper_bound – Maximum distance when masking the values to the mesh cell. Default is 50.

  • max_threshold (float or None, optional) – The maximum value to include in the mask. Any values greater than this threshold will be replaced with the threshold value. Default is None.

  • min_threshold (float or None, optional) – The minimum value to include in the mask. Any values less than this threshold will be replaced with the threshold value. Default is None.

  • cmap –

    the color map name.

    See also

    For full list of supported color map, please refer to Choosing Colormaps in Matplotlib.

  • is_save – weather save the generated figure or not.

  • export_folder – The folder to save the figure.

  • export_name – The filename to save the figure.

  • **kwargs –

    arguments to be passed to pyvista.Plotter.add_mesh().

    See also

    pyvista.Plotter.add_mesh
